column4: Why do users have read access to other users home folders by default?
I don't like that either. chmod o-rwx ~ to change it
yeah, cheers. It's madness. Cannot understand why it's like that.
develpors decided. I don't know why, though.
is that chmod switch saying "Make the owner have read, write and execute of your home folder" thus meaning everyone else does not have that?
no it says revoke read, write and execution perms for others
oh yeah....the - I missed that
you could chmod 750 ~ if you prefer
or 700 even

the problem I have is that I have a mounts folder that points to a drive that I do want other users to access, but it's only mounted from my home folder. So if I apply 750 to ~ they won't be able to navigate to the shared folder.
mount it elsewhere like /mnt/something
UI could do, but it's how I've always had it and I'm kinda used to it now! :-(
I think it's your only option if you restrict access to ~
indeed. I am currently searching the net to try and find the reasoning behind why users are given read access by default. I cannot understand it!
it's common. other users only have read access
I think it's for historical reasons. it's been custom for a long time in *nix I think
but even Windows doesn't allow that AFAIK
it does if you don't tell it not to
does it? I thought it didn't
you can make your files "private" in windows terms
oh yeah - you're right. I remember now
well if samba has read access to your files you can share them even though local users cant access them
as a side note for our previous conversation

thanks nwe. I'm on a different 'concern' now though. I've just migrated from one PC to another and trying to replicate shares that I had on the old machine. Nothing to do with out earlier chat about users home folders :-)
